Issues.Title: Tutorial teaches inaccessible form input coding
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description The tutorial at https://angular.io/start/forms#create-the-checkout-form teaches to place a "label" element above an "input" element but not to associate them with each other programmatically. That violates WCAG and causes assistive technologies to be unable to tell their users what the text inputs are for. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/start/forms#create-the-checkout-form ### Reproduction Steps** ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** ## üì∑Screenshot ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment ### Browser info ### Anything else relevant?

Issues.Title: Docs should not use StackBlitz "generator" or other proprietary features
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... The documentation uses a number of proprietary features of "StackBlitz" online code editor to explain fundamental concepts of Angular. This obscures the process that is occurring when these features, such as "Angular Generator" are used. This is bad practice both due to the fact that there are many reported issues (just do a quick Google search) using StackBlitz, particularly exporting the default project (see here: https://github.com/stackblitz/core/issues/377) and due to the fact that learning from a process that "magically" generates files isn't actually learning anything at all. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Here's an example of part of the docs where this is used: https://angular.io/start#input ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/... https://angular.io/start#input ### Reproduction Steps** Read the docs. See the issue. ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** This isn't a bug. It's a documentation approach issue. ## üì∑Screenshot Unnecessary. ## üî• Exception or Error 



Not a bug.
## üåç Your Environment Not applicable. ### Browser info Not applicable. ### Anything else relevant? Not applicable.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Docs should not use StackBlitz "generator" or other proprietary features" (#31073)

Issues.Title: Docs: Updated browser support documentation required
Issues.Body:
üìö Docs

The browser support documentation is limited. Having spent some time to resolve a brand new v8.0 app not loading in IE11, the suggested workaround is not something anyone is going to find themselves by chance. Also something about the old core-js imports no longer being required would be good. All there is is a note that IE11 needs polyfilling with ES6 with no instruction.

This is the workaround [#14455](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/14455).

[This is the docs page](https://angular.io/guide/browser-support)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Docs: Updated browser support documentation required" (#31071)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/forms): add ng-submitted class
Issues.Body:
Add ng-submitted class to form controls when parent form has been submitted

Fixes #30486

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [x] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->
No class is added to form controls and container when parent form is submitted

Issue Number: 30486


## What is the new behavior?

When parent form is submitted (if there is a parent form), form controls get `ng-submitted` class

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->

Constructor arguments of `NgControlStatus` have changed : we added one optional injected argument `controlContainer`


## Other information

Would it be better to add `submitted` property to `Form` interface (which `NgForm` and `FormGroupDirective` implement) ?

This would avoid the imports of these to directives in `ng_control_status.ts`. I'm afraid that importing them could increase bundle size.

Issues.Title: Glossary: view hierarchy explanation with graphical visualisation
Issues.Body:
üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

The passage on the "view hierarchy" section in the glossary is confusing:
> The view hierarchy doesn't imply a component hierarchy. Views that are embedded in the context of a particular hierarchy can be host views of other components.

It leaves some open questions to me, like:
- Does this mean embedded views of particular components can be reused as host views of other components?
- In what cases a view hierarchy doesn't imply a component hierarchy?


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

### What's the affected URL?**
https://angular.io/guide/glossary#view-tree

### Expected vs Actual Behavior**
#### Actual
The view hierarchy explanation sounds awfully confusing without example or graphical visualisation (even after hours trying to understand it üòì).

#### Expected
The view hierarchy explanation should come along with simplistic hierarchy example, or better yet, with graphical visualisation. Furthermore, I believe it'd help to better understand how the dots are connecting between `ElementRef`, `TemplateRef`, `EmbeddedViewRef`, `ViewRef`, `ComponentRef`, and `ViewContainerRef`.

### Anything else relevant?
When I was looking for an answer on the web, there's already a question on SO regarding this matter, but it doesn't get any answer yet and seems like neither does it get too much attention: https://stackoverflow.com/q/54432451/2013891
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Glossary: view hierarchy explanation with graphical visualisation" (#31066)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): injecting incorrect Renderer2 into child components
Issues.Body:
In ViewEngine injecting a Renderer2 returns a renderer that is specific to the particular component, however in Ivy we inject the renderer for the parent view instead. This causes it to set incorrect `ngcontent` attributes when creating elements through the renderer.

The issue comes from the fact that the `Renderer2` is created according to the current `LView`, but because DI happens before we've entered the `LView` of the component that's injecting the renderer, we end up with one that's one level up. We work around the issue by finding the `LView` that corresponds to the `previousOrParentTNode` inside of the parent view and associating the `Renderer2` with it.

This PR resolves FW-1382.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): injecting incorrect Renderer2 into child components" (#31063)

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for all Angular projects (components, cli, etc).


### Description
Angular does not support TypeScript 3.5.


### Describe the solution you'd like
Add support for TypeScript 3.5.

TypeScript 3.5 sidenote [from here](https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/31639):
"_Note that this release shifts TypeScript from a 2-month release cycle to a 3-month release cycle._"
Hopefully this new release cycle will make it easier for Angular to adopt releases faster.üòâ

Issues.Title: fix(docs-infra): do not auto-link `http://` to the `common/http`
Issues.Body: Previously, our auto-linking feature would match `http` in URLs (such as `http://...`) to the `common/http` package and automatically create a link to that, which was undesirable. While it is possible to work around that via `http://...`, most people didn't even realize the issue. Since in this case it is possible to reliably know it is a false match, this commit fixes it by applying a custom auto-link filter that ignores all docs for `http`, if it comes before `://`. Fixes #31012.

Issues.Title: Whitespaces on HTML
Issues.Body: # üöÄ Feature request ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [x] build - [x] serve ``` ### Description Hello, we're experiencing issues when webpack compiles our application because angular does not allow us to modify whitespace settings. Currently the whitespace settings are not available via the cli config, which causes that each and every single line of HTML code to have a whitespace in between when minified. This settings eventually leads to have HTML code resulting as this: ``` My link .``` And therefore to have a sentence with spaces around clickable. The responsible for the HTML and I have tried to find a way to proceed but we haven't found a consistent solution that solves 100% of the issues, so my question is: Is there any particular reason angular is preventing us to change this setting? ### Describe the solution you'd like Configurable angular-cli or webpack configuration. ### Describe alternatives you've considered Talking with my team we was considering to expand webpack configuration with ngx-build-plus but we think is a problem to be solved on official cli.

Issues.Title: ng serve produces error with web worker active on old project
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [x] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... Previous version did not include web worker ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... I created a project with Angular CLI 7.0.3 some months ago When I ng generate web-worker it generates well, and update files that have to be updated But, I had an error that I describe below. I tried to reproduce with a Angular 8 new project and failed to. I checked differences between my Angular 7 generated project some months ago and the new one, here they are: - tsconfig.app.json does not have a key "include" - tsconfig.app.json was in src folder So I - moved tsconfig.app.json/tsconfig.spec.json to the parent folder - added the line "include": ["src/**/*.ts"], in tsconfig.app.json - updated "extends": "../tsconfig.json" to "extends": "./tsconfig.json", in tsconfig.app.json - updated {projet: architect: options: tsConfig: "src/tsconfig.app.json"} to {projet: architect: options: tsConfig: "tsconfig.app.json"} in tsconfig.json And it worked ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Create a project with Angular CLI 7.0.3 (didn't test any other version) Update to Angular 8 Add a web-worker then ng serve ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: fix(@ngtools/webpack): ensure references for constructor parameter types
Issues.Body: By cloning the import specifier for each of the parameter types, TypeScript's import eliding algorithm will skip removal and prevent reference exceptions at runtime.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@ngtools/webpack): ensure references for constructor parameter types" (#14790)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/cli): ng doc accepts a version flag
Issues.Body:
With this commit, we can now specify a `version`
for the `ng doc` command

    ng doc --version 6
    ng doc -v 6

and this will open `v6.angular.io` instead of `angular.io`.
The default domain is still used
if no version is specified.

Refs #12365

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): improve pipe signature
Issues.Body:
Currently , the CLI generates :

```typescript

transform(value: any , args?: any)

```

With this commit , it generate :

```typescript

transform(value: any, ...args?: any[])

```

Which conforms to the official doc

Fixes #12602

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): emit warning when using extract-i‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶18n in Ivy

i18n is not yet implemented in Ivy, we should emit a warning stating this and exit gracefully.

This also swaps the readTsConfig logic to use `@angular/compiler-cli` instead of `typescript`. This is needed because when parsing the tsconfig, typescript is not aware of `angularCompilerOptions` and will not merged them if they are at un upper level tsconfig file when using `extends`.

Closes #14225

//cc @alxhub
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): emit warning when using extract-i‚Ä¶" (#14771)

Issues.Title: fix(@ngtools/webpack): avoid resetting emit skipped flag when no Type‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
There can be a number of reason why `_emitSkipped` is set to true these are:
- Errors have been encountered
- Changes are outside of TS compilations such as HTML and CSS in JIT mode

We only want to run a full JIT emit when;
- There hasn't been a success emit
- When a large number of files have changed
- First run

If a subsequent JIT build fails we shouldn't do a full emit either as we will transpile only the files that changes after the success build

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/64243919c10c33775be71010efd5ae69622a728f/packages/ngtools/webpack/src/angular_compiler_plugin.ts#L1029-L1031

Fixes #14775
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@ngtools/webpack): avoid resetting emit skipped flag when no Type‚Ä¶" (#14778)

Issues.Title: Rebuild time is not stable anymore in 8.0.3
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report Using @ngtools/webpack 8.0.3, every second rebuild time is high. ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, since 8.0.1. First appeared in 8.0.2 (see #14719), 8.0.3 aimed to fix it, but the fix is half-measure (literally). ### Description Launch `ng serve`, wait for the first build, then touch a component html file and wait its rebuild. I did this few times and wrote down the rebuild times. Version `8.0.3`: ``` Date: 2019-06-14T08:56:30.744Z - Hash: 1510132cb3f52964d65f - Time: 604ms Date: 2019-06-14T08:56:38.832Z - Hash: ed253eed9ef804f511c4 - Time: 3532ms Date: 2019-06-14T08:56:41.848Z - Hash: e6c08a5104db15d947e1 - Time: 515ms Date: 2019-06-14T08:56:46.328Z - Hash: 09d3d86fec4c9a9a8834 - Time: 2672ms Date: 2019-06-14T08:56:48.946Z - Hash: 097aa1913892c8c0686b - Time: 508ms Date: 2019-06-14T08:56:54.344Z - Hash: 202a52c4a542a92a1b29 - Time: 2602ms Date: 2019-06-14T08:56:57.124Z - Hash: 7f1ee6300d02717134b9 - Time: 483ms Date: 2019-06-14T08:57:02.795Z - Hash: 0a543e91e63df3ef126b - Time: 2539ms ``` First rebuild is fast, but every second rebuild is slow. Version: `8.0.2`: ``` Date: 2019-06-14T09:07:16.760Z - Hash: 6097b75a6d66059ebe08 - Time: 3601ms Date: 2019-06-14T09:07:21.965Z - Hash: 6da18789c4ba1a17e497 - Time: 3108ms Date: 2019-06-14T09:07:26.492Z - Hash: d2ff2f0ddee4629d1873 - Time: 2975ms Date: 2019-06-14T09:07:30.964Z - Hash: bfdb111a980b70d79663 - Time: 2650ms Date: 2019-06-14T09:07:35.738Z - Hash: d561e16b9dbb24e847d9 - Time: 3048ms Date: 2019-06-14T09:07:40.500Z - Hash: 5687d30b86313eef337f - Time: 2671ms Date: 2019-06-14T09:07:45.331Z - Hash: 8a729cf663bdc716675f - Time: 2980ms Date: 2019-06-14T09:07:50.294Z - Hash: 448f796097c1c2eca4a6 - Time: 2760ms ``` Every rebuild is slow. Issues.Title: `ng update @angular/material@6` doesn't work as expected
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [x] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? No ### Description [update.angular.io](https://update.angular.io/#5.2:6.0) recommends not to update across multiple major versions. But when trying to update from Angular v5 to v6, `ng update @angular/material@6` updates the project to Angular v8. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I created [Github repo](https://github.com/ahasall/ng-update-v5-v6-repro) reproducing the issue: ```bash git clone https://github.com/ahasall/ng-update-v5-v6-repro.git cd ng-update-v5-v6-repro yarn ng update @angular/material@6 ``` ## üî• Exception or Error First the Angular Material is updated from v5 to v5. Then a TypeScript error that doesn't stop the update process appears:

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular/cli): standardize color handling and support checking
Issues.Body:
Node.js 10+ provides built-in functionality to test for color support based on chalk's `supports-color` package as well as several others. This alleviates the need for custom code or third-party packages to determine color support.  In addition for this PR, the `ansi-colors` package is added to the CLI which provides color, cross-platform symbol, and style/color removal support.  The package is light-weight (~150 SLOC), contains typings, and has no dependencies. The removal support is leveraged to remove all styling from logger messages when color is not supported.  This removes a current defect in which color/styling is still displayed if generated manually or via methods that do not perform supportability checks.  This is very relevant for third-party code/packages.  Finally, the typically used console functions are overriden to leverage the logger to ensure that the color processing is applied to third-party code (e.g., webpack internally as well as some of its loaders and plugins) which output to the console directly.

The color removal capabilities will be leveraged to support improved TypeScript diagnostic reporting which will use TypeScript's built-in functionality that while providing improved messaging and context also includes color.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(@angular/cli): standardize color handling and support checking" (#14780)

Issues.Title: Styling issue when creating a new project
Issues.Body:
Suppose we create a  new project using the command `ng new <project_name> --style=sass`
The new project when created successfully contains a file named `styles.scss` but in and the angular cli build configuration file `angular.json` the file points to `styles.sass` as we are selecting sass preprocessor while creating a new project.

So while serving the project on localhost or building it shows an error of Module not found.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Styling issue when creating a new project" (#14768)

Issues.Title: css paths created after build with base-href not updated
Issues.Body:
### Description
Our company is using Angular, offline, and integrating our app into an already existing one. We are using angular 7, tomcat 9, jdk 11, and the eclipse ide. What is happening is we are making an angular maven webapp and serving it on a tomcat server. It is going well (now), but there is a major snag. We are using a separate library that references the assets/ folder with img src and css url() tags etc. when We Maven build the app using ng build --base-href=/web-vis-angular/ and it deploys well. However when we start the server all the urls are still pointing to assets instead of web-vis-angular/assets. If I pull up the images separately using web-vis-angular/assets/.. I am able to load the images. When I build using a base-href it should be able to replace all the /assets with <your base-href>/assets.


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38532210/how-to-integrate-angular-2-java-maven-web-application
Follow top answer's setup and make a simple hello world that uses a simple css background image url(assets/..). 
You will notice the image doesn't load.

Issues.Title: fix(dialog): don't move focus to dialog container if focus is already inside the dialog
Issues.Body:
This is a follow-up to https://github.com/angular/components/pull/16221. What we hadn't accounted for in the aforementioned PR is that the consumer may have turned off `autoFocus` so that they can handle it themselves and with our changes focus would be reset back to the container. These changes add an extra check which will ensure that focus is only moved if it's not inside the dialog already.

**Note:** I haven't written a test for this for the same reason as #16221: in order to capture the behavior properly, we need to be able to flush a `Promise.resolve` and the animations in a specific sequence, whereas the tests flush them all together.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(dialog): don't move focus to dialog container if focus is already inside the dialog" (#16297)

Issues.Title: .ng-animating not removed in mat-select in webkit
Issues.Body:
There is an issue in webkit browsers with the `mat-select`.  `.ng-animating` is never removed from the panel element.

#### Reproduction

https://github.com/pburkindine/webkit-ng-animating

In this repro, a `mat-select` and a `mat-autocomplete` are included for comparison, with `.ng-animating` set `display: none` to illustrate the issue

Steps to reproduce:
1. Run the app in Chrome and in Safari (issue also exists on all iOS mobile webkit-based browsers, iOS Chrome and Safari both display the problem)
2. Attempt to open mat-select and mat-autocomplete elements
3. Inspect the DOM and view the classlist on the `.mat-select-panel` element to see if `.ng-animating` is removed after animations complete
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Both elements should appear to open even though `.ng-animating` is styled `display: none`

#### Actual Behavior

mat-select and mat-autocomplete will both open fine on Chrome, but only mat-autocomplete will appear to open in Safari


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.0
- CDK/Material: 8.0.1
- Browser(s): Chrome, Safari
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): 
OSX High Sierra, iOS

#### Screenshots

Chrome:
![SS 2019-06-14 at 9 37 44 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20215564/59516995-2640fb00-8e88-11e9-92f1-456bff3813b6.png)


Safari:
![SS 2019-06-14 at 9 35 06 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20215564/59517007-2e009f80-8e88-11e9-85ac-c376bba4a751.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ".ng-animating not removed in mat-select in webkit" (#16295)

Issues.Title: <mat-icon svgIcon="icon_name"> does not resize
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction and Description

When I use standard icons from [Getting started](https://material.angular.io/guide/getting-started#step-6-optional-add-material-icons) I can easily change size of any icon, by changing css `font-size` property. 
However in my angular material app I use icons from
https://dev.materialdesignicons.com/getting-started/angular#angular-material
to change size in this case I should set css `width` and `height` properties. Unfortunately size of icon remains the same. The workaround is, to set `transform: scale(x)`.

To avoid workaround, `<svg>` should have `viewBox="0 0 x y"` attribute. It can be added [here](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/icon/icon-registry.ts#L523) but the problem is to set default viewBox for `MatIconRegistry`. In my case it will always be `viewBox="0 0 24 24"`
 
#### Expected Behavior

Icon should resize.


#### Actual Behavior

Icon does not resize.


#### Environment

- Angular: 7
- CDK/Material: 7
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 7
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "<mat-icon svgIcon="icon_name"> does not resize" (#16293)

Issues.Title: Prevent multiple dialog overlays from blacking out the background
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description
Prevent dark background when multiple dialogs are open.

If you open multiple dialogs without closing them, the background progressively gets darker. While you can configure the backdrop class for when the dialog opens, you can't do much as the dialogs close.

Either add on some sort of `addBackdropClass()` function for `DialogRef`, or manage the overlay internally for all of the open dialogs (leaving only the top dialog with a visible overlay).

#### Use Case
Multiple dialog pop-ups 

(yes, although it's unlikely (and bad UX) that 10 dialogs would open, that doesn't mean that 2 or 3 can't open up. The user should still be able to see what's in the background without it getting darker.)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Prevent multiple dialog overlays from blacking out the background" (#16278)

#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-material-sidenav-tabs-window-resize

Steps to reproduce:
1. click toggle sidenav - the tab header pagination won't show up
2. click raise resize - to trigger ViewportRuler#change 
 
#### Expected Behavior
I think optionally a resize event should be risen when sidnav is toggled. 

#### Actual Behavior
Tab's header won't detect container width change, so pagination won't show up till resizing the window. 
#### Environment

Issues.Title: [mat-menu] programmatic openMenu should not focus first menu option
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-cxsudr?file=app/nested-menu-example.html

Steps to reproduce:
1. Click "Open Menu"
2. First menu option gets focused (wrong)
3. Hovering over the other menu options does not release the first focused menu option
4. After hovering within a sub menu the first menu option's focus is removed
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

When using the programmatic openMenu(), no menu option should get focused.


#### Actual Behavior

First menu option gets focused (and is also not removed during hovering of other menu options).


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.0
- CDK/Material: 8.0.1
- Browser(s): chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[mat-menu] programmatic openMenu should not focus first menu option" (#16275)

Issues.Title: feat(datepicker): expose the validators that the datepicker uses internally as a public API
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-inex9i?file=app%2Fdatepicker-formats-example.ts

#### Steps to reproduce
1. Add a MatDatePicker to a component and bind it to a Reactive form control
2. Ensure you are reporting the built-in parse error (matDatepickerParse) using mat-error
3. Type in a bad date and see the parse error.
4. Call setValidators() on your reactive form control. It doesn't matter what is sent to setValidators
5. Enter invalid data and you will no longer see matDatepickerParse reported

 
#### Expected Behavior

Parsing errors after calling setValidators() should continue to report parsing errors


#### Actual Behavior

Parsing errors are no longer reported.

#### Additional Information
The provided DateAdapter (custom or not) is still used. However, since [datepicker-input](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/917a52e03cca1b3568d29094bbf430846ba1c3c9/src/material/datepicker/datepicker-input.ts) will provide a null value if the provided DateAdapter says the inputted date is invalid, you cannot workaround this issue with a custom validator.

Many complex forms may have conditional validation so using setValidators is completely expected.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.0.0
- CDK/Material: 8.0.1
- Browser(s): Google Chrome 73.0.3683.75 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- Operating System Windows 10 64-bit
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(datepicker): expose the validators that the datepicker uses internally as a public API" (#16274)

Issues.Title: [Table] Mat cell definitions do not ensure correct typing
Issues.Body:
Cell definitions like ```html {{element.position}} ``` do not enforce typing. Even if table `dataSource` ```html ``` is properly typed, `let element` is still of type `any`, which does not allow the TypeScript compiler to type-check the markup inside the cell definition. On the test page (https://stackblitz.com/edit/mat-tables-typing), I modified the [table-basic](https://github.com/angular/components/tree/master/src/material-examples/table-basic) example from the repo to output a non-existing field (`element.non_existing_field`), and the project is still compiled without any TypeScript errors. I am sure I does not need to explain how beneficial strong typing is for early detection of programming errors. Furthermore, TypeScript and strong typing is one of the principal features of Angular as a framework, so I consider it great shame that this feature is not properly leveraged here. I am not an expert in Angular, so please let me know if there are some Angular limitations that prevent Angular Material from providing proper typing support. I will appreciate if you point me to an appropriate ticket in Angular project I could watch. #### Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/mat-tables-typing #### Expected Behavior In a cell definition like ```html ``` the `element` variable should receive a TypeScript type derived from the type of `dataSource` input passed to `mat-table`. Changing the cell definition into ```html ``` should cause TypeScript errors to be emitted when the project is AOT-compiled. #### Actual Behavior The `element` variable receives type `any`. Changing the cell definition into ```html ``` does not trigger any TypeScript errors. I believe, you will have to download the StackBlitz project locally in order to check this. #### Environment - Angular: 8.0.0 - CDK/Material: 8.0.0 - Browser(s): Google Chrome | 74.0.3729.169¬†(Official Build)¬†(64-bit) - Operating System: Windows 10
{{element.position}} {{element.non_existing_field}} {{element.non_existing_field}}
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Table] Mat cell definitions do not ensure correct typing" (#16273)
